The Popular Vote of Interop 2024 â€” We will soon be learning what the focus for Interop will be in 2024, but ahead of that Chris attempts to tally up what proposals might be front and centre in terms of attention (from a total of 103!) â€” including scroll-driven animations, JPEG XL, andÂ more.

CSS Media Query for Scripting Support â€” A new â€˜scriptingâ€™ media query (e.g. @media (scripting: none)), recently added to Chrome, looks to be a powerful addition to the progressive enhancement toolbox â€” it allows you to test whether scripting languages are available and tailor page content and styles based uponÂ this.

CSS Hooks

remoteStorage: A Cross Browser/Device Persistence Approach â€” Combines the localStorage API with a remote server to persist data across browsers and devices â€“Â so basically, imagine localStorage but remote. Hereâ€™s how the server partÂ runs.

Frigade

Tuple sponsor

Makedraft: An AI That Generates Frontend Code Based on Instructions â€” Will generate HTML with Tailwind, JavaScript, or Alpine.js. Also includes the option to highlight code you want changed before adding your text in theÂ prompt.

makedraft

subiRegex: Generate Regular Expressions with English â€” Type something like â€œCanadian Postal Codeâ€ or â€œ5 numbers followed by an optional letterâ€, etc. and this tool will generate the regex for you usingÂ AI.

Jonathan Kong Boon Lieng

Direction-Aware Mickey Mouse â€” Everyoneâ€™s been talking about the copyright status of Steamboat Willie lately, so hereâ€™s Mickey following your pointer and keeping an eye onÂ thingsâ€¦

Jon Kantner CodePen

Tailplates: A Set of 20+ Responsive Tailwind CSS Templates â€” Includes four categories of templates: agency, blog, ecommerce, and SaaS, with eight different page variations. Not a free project, but the price seems reasonable at $10 for theÂ set.

Tailplates

items.title: A look back at 2023 in frontend development
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹624 â€” January 3, 2024 | Read on the web

âœï¸ Hello, and happy new year! We're kicking off 2024 with a look back over the past twelve months, bringing you the highlights of what we've shared in Frontend Focus â€”Â you're bound to find something worth revisiting, bookmarking or sharing on. 2023 was a bountiful year, with the likes of CSS nesting, :has(), and much more arriving and having an impact on how we work.

If you've enjoyed the newsletter, please consider forwarding it to a friend â€”Â perhaps even someone starting their frontend journey this year. Let's get started, and thanks for reading!
__
Your editor, Chris Brandrick

ğŸ—“ï¸ Top Ten of 2023

01:Â Six CSS Snippets Every Front-End Developer Should Know in 2023 â€” This look at a half-dozen toolbelt worthy, powerful, and broadly cross-compatible CSS techniques (including logical properties and container queries) proved very popular, and was the top link shared in Frontend Focus last year. Everything remains relevant in 2024 too, of course!Â ğŸ˜

Adam Argyle

Tackle Any HTML & CSS Challenge â€” Join Jen Kramer for this video course to practice and refine your CSS skills. Work through five projects leveraging various CSS layout techniques such as flexbox and grid, learn responsive design strategies, develop a strategy for supporting multiple devices, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

02:Â A Deep Dive Into SVG Path Commands â€” A very well presented, interactive guide to understanding SVG paths and path commands â€” it covers cursors, lines, bÃ©zier curves, and more, and remains a bookmark-worthyÂ resource.

Nanda Syahrasyad

03:Â If Web Components Are So Great, Why Am I Not Using Them? â€” There was plenty of renewed chatter and attention on Web Components in the latter half of 2023, kicked off in part by Dave's analysis on the 'marketing problem' that this relatively slowly-adopted technology may have.

Dave Rupert

â„¹ï¸ Other notable Web Components posts shared last year include Jake Lazaroff's piece on how they will 'outlive your JavaScript framework', a handy collection of related resources from Zach Leatherman, and this explainer/example from Jim Nielsen.

04:Â â–¶ï¸ 21 Awesome Web Features Youâ€™re Not Using Yet â€” An eight-minute video that's closing in on nearly a million views now. It runs through some of the then-new features on the web platform, and remains a solid high-level, informative runÂ through.

Fireship

05:Â A Blog Post with Every HTML Element â€” A mammoth effort here â€” it's a bold attempt to squeeze every single valid HTML element (along with some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place.

Patrick Weaver

Product for Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your ProductÂ Muscle â€” Subscribe for free to get curated advice on building great products and best practices of top startups fromÂ PostHog.

PostHog sponsor

06:Â Ten Weird HTML Hacks That Shaped the Internet â€” A superb, curious history lesson here looking back at old table hacks, CSS kludges, and various quirky coding strategies that helped web developers get things looking good before we had the modern tools at our disposalÂ now.

Ernie Smith

07:Â The Top Front-End Tools of 2022 â€” It might feel a bit dated to share a 2022 round-up in 2024, but this collection of handy frontend tools remains relevant nonetheless with plenty of tools to help speed up yourÂ workflow.

Louis Lazaris

08:Â The Truth About CSS Selector Performance â€” It's true. Certain CSS selectors are faster than others. This article explains, outlining the ones that are important to keep an eye on for performance.

Patrick Brosset

09:Â An Interactive Guide to CSS Grid â€” An excellent primer from Josh on all things CSS Grid, sharing a mental model we can adopt in order to best understand how CSS Grid works and how we can use it effectively.

Josh Comeau

ğŸ—“ï¸Â [Workshop] An Intro To Debugging Next.js With Sentry â€” Join us to learn: Sentry basics, how to identify Next.js issues, and if an error occurred on the client or serverÂ side.

Sentry sponsor

10:Â The 'End' of Front-End Development â€” Another from Josh, this time addressing the rise of AI language models and how they may impact programming. Josh noted he was â€œmuch more optimistic about what these AI advancements mean for the future of softwareÂ developmentâ€.

Josh W. Comeau

âš¡ï¸ Some 2023 Bonus Items

  • It's time to learn OKLCH Color
  • Five best practices for preventing chaos in Tailwind CSS
  • The ongoing defence of frontend as a full-time job
  • 11 HTML best practices for login & sign-up forms
  • The guide to responsive design in 2023 and beyond â€” welcome to the beyond, IÂ guess!

â„¹ï¸ Normal service resumes next week, catch you then! â€” Chris ğŸ‘‹

 If you've enjoyed the newsletter, please consider forwarding it to a friend â€”Â perhaps even someone starting their frontend journey this year. Let's get started, and thanks for reading! 
__
Your editor, Chris Brandrick


ğŸ—“ï¸ Top Ten of 2023


  
  
01:Â Six CSS Snippets Every Front-End Developer Should Know in 2023 â€” This look at a half-dozen toolbelt worthy, powerful, and broadly cross-compatible CSS techniques (including logical properties and container queries) proved very popular, and was the top link shared in Frontend Focus last year. Everything remains relevant in 2024 too, of course!Â ğŸ˜
Adam Argyle 





  
  
Tackle Any HTML & CSS Challenge â€” Join Jen Kramer for this video course to practice and refine your CSS skills. Work through five projects leveraging various CSS layout techniques such as flexbox and grid, learn responsive design strategies, develop a strategy for supporting multiple devices, andÂ more.
Frontend Masters sponsor





  
  
02:Â A Deep Dive Into SVG Path Commands â€” A very well presented, interactive guide to understanding SVG paths and path commands â€” it covers cursors, lines, bÃ©zier curves, and more, and remains a bookmark-worthyÂ resource.
Nanda Syahrasyad 


  
  
03:Â If Web Components Are So Great, Why Am I Not Using Them? â€” There was plenty of renewed chatter and attention on Web Components in the latter half of 2023, kicked off in part by Dave's analysis on the 'marketing problem' that this relatively slowly-adopted technology may have.
Dave Rupert 


â„¹ï¸ Other notable Web Components posts shared last year include Jake Lazaroff's piece on how they will 'outlive your JavaScript framework', a handy collection of related resources from Zach Leatherman, and this explainer/example from Jim Nielsen.





  
  
04:Â â–¶ï¸ 21 Awesome Web Features Youâ€™re Not Using Yet â€” An eight-minute video that's closing in on nearly a million views now. It runs through some of the then-new features on the web platform, and remains a solid high-level, informative runÂ through.
Fireship 


  
  
05:Â A Blog Post with Every HTML Element â€” A mammoth effort here â€” it's a bold attempt to squeeze every single valid HTML element (along with some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place.
Patrick Weaver 





  
  
Product for Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your ProductÂ Muscle â€” Subscribe for free to get curated advice on building great products and best practices of top startups fromÂ PostHog.
PostHog sponsor





  
  
06:Â Ten Weird HTML Hacks That Shaped the Internet â€” A superb, curious history lesson here looking back at old table hacks, CSS kludges, and various quirky coding strategies that helped web developers get things looking good before we had the modern tools at our disposalÂ now.
Ernie Smith 


  
  
07:Â The Top Front-End Tools of 2022 â€” It might feel a bit dated to share a 2022 round-up in 2024, but this collection of handy frontend tools remains relevant nonetheless with plenty of tools to help speed up yourÂ workflow.
Louis Lazaris 


  
  
08:Â The Truth About CSS Selector Performance â€” It's true. Certain CSS selectors are faster than others. This article explains, outlining the ones that are important to keep an eye on for performance.
Patrick Brosset 


  
  
09:Â An Interactive Guide to CSS Grid â€” An excellent primer from Josh on all things CSS Grid, sharing a mental model we can adopt in order to best understand how CSS Grid works and how we can use it effectively. 
Josh Comeau 





  
  
ğŸ—“ï¸Â [Workshop] An Intro To Debugging Next.js With Sentry â€” Join us to learn: Sentry basics, how to identify Next.js issues, and if an error occurred on the client or serverÂ side.
Sentry sponsor





  
  
10:Â The 'End' of Front-End Development â€” Another from Josh, this time addressing the rise of AI language models and how they may impact programming. Josh noted he was â€œmuch more optimistic about what these AI advancements mean for the future of softwareÂ developmentâ€.
Josh W. Comeau 







âš¡ï¸ Some 2023 Bonus Items
It's time to learn OKLCH Color
Five best practices for preventing chaos in Tailwind CSS
The ongoing defence of frontend as a full-time job
11 HTML best practices for login & sign-up forms
The guide to responsive design in 2023 and beyond â€” welcome to the beyond, IÂ guess!














â„¹ï¸ Normal service resumes next week, catch you then! â€” Chris ğŸ‘‹

Thank you so much for reading along with us this year â€”Â as ever, we hope the newsletter continues to provide you value and shines a light on helpful resources. Getting Started with Web Performance â€” A solid look at how to up your web performance game, with strategies, tools and tips to help you make notable improvements. Lots of additional resources shared here too to help you push thingsÂ further. Maybe a nice end of year project, making things speedier as we head into the new year?

Alistair Shepherd

Firefox 121 Released: New Features, Updates & Fixes â€” A big release of Firefox just before the holidays (it shipped yesterday), featuring support for the :has() selector, <iframe> lazy loading, updated text-wrap property support, and more. Full developer-focused notesÂ here.

Mozilla

â­ï¸ RELATED: Following the release of Firefox 121, :has() is now supported across all major browsers. Wes Bos runs through the possibilities itÂ unlocks.

Session Replay Basics - Debug Web App IssuesÂ Faster â€” Tired of â€œworks fine on my machineâ€ and spending time chasing elusive issues (like Hydration errors)? Join us on Jan 11th to learn how Session Replay can help confirm and resolve even the most difficult-to-repro issues in JavaScriptÂ applications.

Sentry sponsor

Baseline in 2023 â€” Baseline is now added to the invaluable Can I Use. Rachel explains how the new integration works here, and highlights what features became part of the Baseline inÂ 2023.

Rachel Andrew

Figma and Adobe Abandon Proposed Merger â€” 15 months after announcing the deal, the companies no longer see a path toward regulatoryÂ approval. Figma will get a meaty billion dollar check from Adobe.

Dylan Field (Figma)

  • ğŸ›¡ï¸ There's a new 'Micro' set of 16x16 pixel icons in Heroicons v2.1 (an SVG icon set from the Tailwind CSSÂ folks).

CSS animation-composition â€” How to use the CSS animation-composition property for advanced control over how values are applied during keyframeÂ animations.

Tyler Gaw

ğŸ¤¨ Bramus Van Damme follows up to the above, explaining the quirks of using animation-composition: accumulate on a scale transform.

CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned with Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study â€” Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? This article demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container, sharing a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on theÂ page.

Brecht De Ruyte

Kickstart Your 2024 Developer Career with Scrimba â€” Scrimbaâ€™s online bootcamp can turn you into a hireable Frontend Dev in 3-6 months. Frontend Focus readers get 25% off! Offer ends DecÂ 31.

Scrimba sponsor

The Shrinkwrap Problem: Possible Future Solutions â€” How anchor positioning can help tackle a CSS problem: shrinking containers to fit content when it automaticallyÂ wraps.

Roman Komarov

Using Date-Based CSS to Make Old Web Pages Look Old â€” Explores a way to access the published date metadata of a page in order to change the CSS based on itsÂ age.

Terence Eden

Three Modern CSS Properties Your Site Must Have â€” A look at three â€œlesser-known CSS secretsâ€ that can go some way to help fix some UI problems on yourÂ website.

Mojtaba Seyedi

â–¶Â Â Igalia Chats: 2023 Year in Review â€” Brian Kardell and Eric Meyer chat with Chrome DevRel Bramus Van Damme, reviewing the year of change in the Web Platform in an hour longÂ discussion.

Igalia podcast

Locking Scroll with :has() â€” A neat, handy little trick that uses :has() to prevent accidental page scrolling when modals areÂ open.

Robb Owen

Ten Optimization Tips for an Initial Web Perf Audit
Alistair Shepherd

Fallbacks for HTTP 404 Images in HTML and JS
Salma Alam-Naylor

26 Web Dev Terms You May Not Have Heard Of
Jens Oliver Meiert

A Mental Model for Styling the Shadow DOM
Nathan Knowler

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Announcing SvelteKit 2 â€” SvelteKit (the official toolkit for building Svelte webapps) is now one year old, and despite its relative youth, the framework has been quickly embraced by the community. This release is a relatively incremental one, adding support for Vite 5, and laying the groundwork for SvelteÂ 5.

Svelte

Empowering a Creator Economy with â€˜Game-Changingâ€™ Analytics Dashboards â€” See how Patch helps Hubla deliver interactive, customer-facing analytics dashboards with zero infrastructureÂ setup.

Patch sponsor

pagefind-search Web Component â€” This implements PageFind search in an Eleventy app using Eleventy island support (via the is-landÂ component).

Zach Leatherman

Open Source Software: Open Source Alternatives to PopularÂ Projects â€” Currently includes 500+ projects that can be searched via keyword or via category filters (analytics, APIs, monitoring, terminal, authentication, etc).

john rush

NinjaBootstrap: A Collection of SCSS Utilities to Extend BootstrapÂ 5 â€” Includes utilities for spacing, positioning, sizing, borders, and color theming, allowing you to have a little more control over Bootstrapâ€™s defaultÂ classes.

Live Canvas

SVG.io: Generate Custom SVG Images from a Text Prompt â€” Simpler prompts will have better results and itâ€™s free to use with no limitations (for now!). The generated SVG is monochrome but could be customized in your SVG editor ofÂ choice. I had mixed success, but it's an interestingÂ idea.

Digital Pixel

Catch you in two weeks! â€” Chris ğŸ‘‹
